meaning_mnemonic: You have to take the <radical>measurement</radical> of a <radical>leader</radical>. Imagine yourself measuring that leader's height and then coming up short. This is not good, you think. Leaders need to be at least six feet tall. So, to make the leader tall enough, you <kanji>attach</kanji> another head to the top of the leader's head.
meaning_hint: Make sure you really feel like the person can’t be a leader because they’re too short when you measure them (I know this isn’t true, but we’re remembering kanji here, anything goes!). As long as you feel disconcerted that the leader isn’t tall enough, you should be able to remember that you need to attach something to the leader to make them tall enough. The fact that you’re attaching another head to the top of the leader's head is pretty weird too, and should help you to remember the meaning.
reading_mnemonic: You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is つ. So, think of <kanji>attach</kanji>ing something to something else. What would you need? You'd need <reading>two</reading> (つ) things to put together!
reading_hint: Just focus on how attaching requires two things to remember this reading.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>lion</radical> drops a <radical>drop</radical> of saliva onto this <radical>person</radical> <kanji>from</kanji> above. The person is in a much worse place <kanji>compared with</kanji> where they were before, <kanji>since</kanji> they only just recently fell into this pit.
meaning_hint: Picture the person, the lion is leaning over them, the drop of spit dangling from their mouth. "I-I want to go back where I came from," the person gasps, shaking.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>From</kanji> above there is a loud caw, and a giant <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) swoops down, forcing the lion to back off. The eagle grabs the person with its talons, bringing him into the air! But now he's... in the air being carried by a giant eagle, <kanji>compared with</kanji> where he was before, is this really better?!
reading_hint: The eagle came from the sky and technically rescued him, but compared to where he was before, it may not be a better situation. I think this person is going to be eaten either way.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> <radical>leaf</radical> grows only in the <radical>winter</radical>. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the <kanji>summer</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Just think of the eye leaf as weird (it is weird, after all). It grows in the winter. Now, think of any normal leaves. They do the exact opposite, which is to grow in the summer.
reading_mnemonic: Now it's summertime! What do you do during the <kanji>summer</kanji>? You just sit around with your favorite string tying <reading>knots</reading> (なつ) in it over and over again.
reading_hint: Think about summer. Now think about yourself tying knots. Now think about summer again. Now think about tying knots again. Now think about your mother getting upset at you because all you do is tie knots all summer long. Go play video games like a normal kid!

meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>slide</radical> is your <radical>husband</radical>'s only <kanji>fault</kanji>. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.
meaning_hint: Imagine looking out the window of your house and watching your husband slide down his slide over and over. He's not even good at it, he falls off the side halfway down most of the time. You want to complain, but he's pretty decent otherwise. This is his only fault.
reading_mnemonic: You try to come up with another <kanji>fault</kanji> of his so you can complain, when you see a tiny <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ) trotting by. Oh no! Before you can call out, your husband has fallen off the slide and crushed the poor thing. You hear a sharp yelp and then nothing.
reading_hint: You run outside and yell, "AHA! It's your fault that shih tzu died! You and that stupid slide!"

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>canopy</radical>, you use a <radical>tree</radical> for your <kanji>floor</kanji>. It also becomes your <kanji>bed</kanji>, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed?
meaning_hint: You lay it down, cut it into slats, and voila! A floor! And a bed!
reading_mnemonic: It's great having a <kanji>floor</kanji> or <kanji>bed</kanji>, but whenever you use it you say <reading>yucka</reading> (ゆか) because it just gets so dirty. That's the one flaw of using a floor as a bed. In fact, it's the dirtiest floor you've ever seen, because it's covered in <reading>yucca</reading> (ゆか) leaves. You're sleeping on a yucca floor. Ew!
reading_hint: You can imagine how comfortable it is to sleep on a floor of yucca leaves, but at the same time how horrible the smell must be when they start to rot.

meaning_mnemonic: You have two <radical>bow</radical>s but they're both covered in <radical>ice</radical>. This has made them very <kanji>weak</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Just look at these weak, iced over bows. If you tried to draw back their strings they'd snap into a million pieces.
reading_mnemonic: You give up on your trip and bring the <kanji>weak</kanji> bows back to your car, but it's stuck in the ice and snow. You decide to use the bows as a <reading>jack</reading> (じゃく) to try to get your car unstuck. Unfortunately, they're just too weak and they break in half.
reading_hint: Now you're stuck with two weak broken bows and no jack. Ice is lame.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>private</radical> <radical>bow</radical> made of <radical>insect</radical>s that's extremely <kanji>strong</kanji>. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for strong bows. You also have to be strong to use it, since it was made just for strong arms.
meaning_hint: Imagine holding this strong bow in your strong arms. Look closer at the little insect bodies that make it up. Thanks for your help, little guys.
reading_mnemonic: You had this <kanji>strong</kanji> bow made especially for you in <reading>きょう</reading>と. きょうと is famous for their strong bows, so if you ever want another, you know where to go.
reading_hint: Imagine all the strong people who live in きょうと and make strong things. You should go there someday!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> coming out of the patient's <radical>heart</radical> is there because a mad scientist is testing to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive now... but they are definitely slated for <kanji>certain</kanji> death.
meaning_hint: As you imagine the mad scientist drawing blood out of the patient's heart with a small slide, also imagine a little meter hooked up to him as well. On one end is "SURVIVE!" on the other end is "CERTAIN DEATH." Right now the finger is pointing close to <kanji>certain</kanji> death, though :(
reading_mnemonic: As the beeping heart thing starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the doctor puts his hands together and <reading>hits</reading> (ひつ) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back.
reading_hint: Maybe imagine yourself running in there too, just trying to <reading>hit</reading> the patient back to life, because the patient was your friend.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>teacher</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> is happiest because they get to <kanji>teach</kanji>! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!
meaning_hint: Picture a teacher excitedly teaching, bundled up in the cold. Snow falling outside. Grumpy children being taught inside.
reading_mnemonic: Teachers can teach the most about Japan in winter by going to <reading>きょう</reading>と. きょうと is where all the old temples and history of Japan is centered. And it's really gorgeous when it snows.
reading_hint: Imagine the teaching teacher teaching you about Japan in きょうと in winter. You've always wanted to go to きょうと!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> in the <radical>center</radical> of the sky gives off its light, which <kanji>reflect</kanji>s off of everything around it.
meaning_hint: Look around you, everything you see is reflecting the light of the sun. Unless it's night time, then the tiny sun in the center of your lightbulb is creating the light that reflects there.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>reflect</kanji>ed light is important for <reading>a</reading>corns (えい), in particular. Without light reflecting off everything, the sun's light would never make it down to the ground where they've fallen. They would never grow into trees. And we'd all suffocate.
reading_hint: Picture the light of the sun reflecting off a single acorn on the forest floor. So much symbolism!

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>sun</radical> is used in a <radical>temple</radical> to tell <kanji>time</kanji>. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now."

This also can mean <kanji>o' clock</kanji>, as in "five o'clock" It's used when measuring what time it is in Japanese.
meaning_hint: Imagine being in a temple and realizing you don't know what time it is. Never fear! Look on up at the sun. Ah, yes. Blinding noon.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Time</kanji> in a temple makes you think of <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). Specifically, Jesus being able to perform time travel magic. He winks at you, goes back to the dinosaur ages, where he wrestles a T-rex. Then, he goes to WWII era and punches Hitler in the mouth.
reading_hint: Imagine him going to all kinds of different times and also make sure you're specifically imagining Jesus doing all these things. Put these two together and you'll remember the reading in no time. (Haha, get it?)

meaning_mnemonic: You're flying in a <radical>jet</radical>. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "<kanji>Not yet</kanji>! Not yet! NOT YET!"
meaning_hint: Feel the irritation of this. How irritating is this kid going to be the whole flight over? The jet is going as fast as it can!
reading_mnemonic: What a selfish kid, right? Well, all he thinks about is "<reading>Me</reading> (み) me me me me me me me me me me." Hate kids like that.
reading_hint: Go ahead and pretend to listen to the kid asking if we're there yet. Then in your mind go "me me me me me me me" quietly.

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji uses a modified <radical>jet</radical> radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the <kanji>end</kanji> of the earth.
meaning_hint: Imagine the end of the earth being like how they imagined it pre-Columbus era. Just a big drop going off into space, giant waterfalls plummeting down. Your crazy jet has made it to the very end! Congratulations!
reading_mnemonic: When you get to the <kanji>end</kanji> of the world, you land your jet and put out a few <reading>mats</reading> (まつ) to sit on so you can view the sights.
reading_hint: It's surprisingly dirty down here, because all the water takes the garbage this way. That's why you sit on these mats you brought.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>umbrella</radical>, which it's holding over its head. Strange, because trees normally like water… Turns out, this tree wasn't getting showered in water, but in dollar <kanji>bill</kanji>s instead.
meaning_hint: The sick part is that all those bills were once this tree's friends. Picture the tree sobbing uncontrollably, as pieces of its former friends fall everywhere around it. No wonder it needs that umbrella.
reading_mnemonic: And the person who gave the tree an umbrella to protect it from all those <kanji>bills</kanji>? <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ), a little girl famous for… handing out umbrellas, I guess. Makes sense that Satsuki would take care of these bills then.
reading_hint: Try to remember this little girl named Satsuki, since she'll come up whenever the reading for a kanji is さつ (there's a good handful of them). Picture her in your mind, with details like her hair and clothes. Maybe even holding an umbrella or standing by a tree? You should also know she's kind of a bookworm, I guess, in terms of personality. If you can imagine her clearly now, it'll be easy to remember さつ kanji later on.

meaning_mnemonic: Next to the <radical>tree</radical>, a <radical>lid</radical> is put on your <radical>father</radical>. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new <kanji>school</kanji>."
meaning_hint: He goes on to explain that he changed your school to here because there is a tree to block the satellite's view. Also, he wears a tin foil lid on his head so they can't track him. The regular school was no good because "they were watching." So now you have this new school, taught under a tree by your father who's wearing a lid on his head.
reading_mnemonic: Your new <kanji>school</kanji> has other students too. They are all <reading>こう</reading>いちs, though.
reading_hint: On your first day of school, imagine walking under the tree and seeing all your classmates. They're all こういち–similar to each other, but with some variation. Your father explains these こういちs escaped from a government research facility, and they come to this school to receive a better education.  "These poor こういちs need a school that will teach them more than just kanji and Japanese vocabulary."

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. <radical>Lack</radical> becomes <kanji>Lack</kanji>!
meaning_hint: If you know the radical you know this.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember けつ, we use the word "ketsup." It's the perfect blend of ketchup and catsup!

You're <kanji>lack</kanji>ing something in your fridge. You look around, trying to find the <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ) you lack. You can't find it, because you lack it.
reading_hint: Imagine having to use regular, ordinary ketchup, or just old, boring catsup on your burger. Or even worse, an actual tomato. BLEH!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is where you get your name. But not your given name, your <kanji>family name</kanji>. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your <kanji>surname</kanji>! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
meaning_hint: Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!
reading_mnemonic: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your <kanji>family name</kanji> came from. Your family used to herd <reading>shee</reading>p (し). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.
reading_hint: Imagine your ancestors, herding sheep. Thanks to them your name means "sheep people." Thanks, great-great-great-great-great-grandpappy.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>clan</radical> are a group of <kanji>people</kanji>. They are the <kanji>people</kanji> of a <kanji>nation</kanji>.
meaning_hint: The mouth clan are distinct peoples. They do, of course, use their mouths.
reading_mnemonic: The mouth clan <kanji>peoples</kanji> are a <kanji>nation</kanji> of <kanji>people</kanji> who use their mouths to say <reading>mean</reading> (みん) things to other peoples.
reading_hint: That's why they're the mouth clan. This nation of people are known for mouthing off and saying mean things. Imagine them, as a nation, saying mean things to you. How awful! All being from the same place, they're all into it too. In a way, they're not the mouth clan, they're the mean clan.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical>'s <radical>village</radical> is the <kanji>reason</kanji> he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place.
meaning_hint: If a king has no one to rule then he has no reason to exist.
reading_mnemonic: You can't have <kanji>reason</kanji> without <reading>re</reading> (り).
reading_hint: Just like you can't have a king without a village, you can't have reason without re.

meaning_mnemonic: A giant <radical>cross</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> stands above you. "I am <kanji>reason</kanji>!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.
meaning_hint: Because it's a cross with a mouth, it thinks that it is reason in all the chaos.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>reason</kanji> that this Cross of Reason exists is to combat the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) of the world, who just bring chaos into everything.
reading_hint: "Those youths just do things for no reason! That's why I, the Cross of Reason, am here! I will knock some reason into those youths."

meaning_mnemonic: You go down a <radical>street</radical> that cuts through a <radical>rice paddy</radical> and leads to a <radical>box</radical>. When you open the box at the end of the street, you see it's full of <kanji>image</kanji>s. Image after image. <kanji>Drawing</kanji>, <kanji>painting</kanji>, you name it. Someone must have left this box of images here.
meaning_hint: What are the images of, anyway? Well, it's better not to say out loud. Just think of the kind of image you enjoy looking at most. That's what's in the box at the end of the street. Aren't you the lucky one?
reading_mnemonic: Okay, I didn't want to tell you this, but the <kanji>image</kanji>s are all <kanji>drawing</kanji>s and <kanji>painting</kanji>s of <reading>ga</reading>rgoyles (が) and <reading>cock</reading>s (かく). Male chickens, that is. Turns out that's what you wanted to see most. Don't worry, no one is judging you.
reading_hint: Try to see the images of the gargoyles. Winged, stony monsters. Very cool. And the roosters? Colorful little dinosaurs. What's not to like?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> that ties you to your <radical>clan</radical> is <kanji>paper</kanji>. Your papers, that is.
meaning_hint: The paper itself was also made by your clan using thread woven really tightly together.
reading_mnemonic: You need this specific <kanji>paper</kanji> to prove that you aren't a <reading>Commi</reading> (かみ), aka a Communist. Or that you are. It really depends on where you want to go and what decade this is.
reading_hint: Imagine a big guard coming up to you and asking to see your papers so they can see what clan you belong to. Well you're from the Commi clan, so you really hope this guard is okay with that.

meaning_mnemonic: Sew <radical>thread</radical> through your <radical>top hat</radical> and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a <kanji>group</kanji> of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.
meaning_hint: Picture a group of people threaded together by their top hats. Don't you want to be part of a cool group like that? Your own top hat team.
reading_mnemonic: Everyone in this <kanji>group</kanji> loves <reading>cumi</reading>n (くみ). You know, the spice or seed. The group take off their top hats and fill them with cumin. You're officially a group for lovers of cumin.
reading_hint: What do you do in the cumin group? You smell the cumin. Cook with it it. Taste it. This group lives and breathes cumin!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>boat</radical> has <radical>fins</radical> and a <radical>mouth</radical>! It's still a <kanji>boat</kanji> though.
meaning_hint: Picture this boat. It's still a boat, but there is a big mouth on the front and it has fins that it paddles forward with.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>boat</kanji> belongs to the <reading>cen</reading>taurs (せん). That's probably why you've never seen a boat like it before.
reading_hint: Picture this mouth and boat with a bunch of centaurs riding in it. Centaurs have a lot more parts than humans, so it makes sense that their boats have more parts (animal ones) too.

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> to <radical>oneself</radical> (yourself), you decide to <kanji>write down</kanji>. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to <kanji>record</kanji> these important thoughts in some way.
meaning_hint:
Just imagine writing in a diary and saying everything to write aloud to yourself in your head. 

"Dear me, today I learned a lot of new kanji on WaniKani. It was the best. I love the crabigator sooooo much. Love, me."
reading_mnemonic: You need to protect what you <kanji>write down</kanji> and <kanji>record</kanji> for yourself with a <reading>key</reading> (き). These are your special thoughts and feelings, you don't want anyone else to see! Lock them away with a key!
reading_hint: Picture the key you use to keep what you write down a secret. What does it look like? How does it feel in your hands?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>elephant</radical> radical and the <kanji>elephant</kanji> kanji are the same. But! This kanji has another meaning: <kanji>phenomenon</kanji>. If you were the first person to see an elephant, you'd call it that too.
meaning_hint: Picture the first Japanese person to see an elephant. He stops dead in his tracks, points and screams out, "What a phenomenon!"
reading_mnemonic:
<kanji>Elephant</kanji>s are great and all, except that when they die they turn into elephant <reading>zo</reading>mbies (ぞう). But you never see these zombies because the <reading>shou</reading>gun (しょう) has a special project in place that destroys all elephant bodies when they die.

Hint: The readings and meanings for this kanji match up really nicely. ぞう is always for elephant and しょう is always for phenomenon. Remember it like this, the elephant is the zombie and the shougun keeps everyone from finding out about this phenomenon.
reading_hint: Picture the shougun standing over a pit of zombie elephants. None of these are getting out on his watch, letting people believe in such crazy phenomenons.

meaning_mnemonic: While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you take your <radical>sword</radical> and cut out an <kanji>area</kanji> on the ground.  You carefully cut all the <kanji>side</kanji>s as you go. This area's all yours now!
meaning_hint: Imagine riding your scooter around in a really large area, pressing your sword into the ground as you do. Once you've finished carving out the sides of the entire area, you claim to everyone around that this is YOUR area, and they aren't allowed in.
reading_mnemonic: As you look down at your <kanji>area</kanji> with its sword-carved <kanji>side</kanji>s, you suddenly realize there is a <reading>hen</reading> (へん) pecking at the ground in there. "Um, excuse me, hen, I believe I said this is MY area?!" You try to kick it out, but it hops over your leg.
reading_hint: Imagine doing everything you can to get this hen out of your area, but it manages to dodge and outwit you at every turn. You even slash at it with your sword and try to run it over with your scooter, but the hen can't be stopped. This is the hen's area now. You have been defeated.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>scooter</radical> with your <radical>mama</radical> carrying a <radical>task</radical> she needs to get done. You see her <kanji>pass through</kanji>, hurrying by to get that task done.
meaning_hint: Imagine your mama passing through your house on a scooter, not stopping because she needs to get her task done urgently.
reading_mnemonic: As you watch your mama <kanji>pass through</kanji> the house, she yells, "YOU HAVE TO DO THIS TASK <reading>TOO</reading> (つう)!" Too?! Oh no, now you have to do it too. Hurry up!
reading_hint: Why do you have to do the task too? Because there are two tasks, so the two of you have to do them.

meaning_mnemonic: Use a <radical>scooter</radical> to travel the <radical>circumference</radical> of the world and it will take you a full <kanji>week</kanji>. Seven whole days!
meaning_hint: A week in earth time is also known as a "full scoot" in scooter lingo. ;)
reading_mnemonic: If you want to scoot for a <kanji>week</kanji>, you'll need <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). Good shoes too, not sandals or high heels or boots. Solid, high quality shoes, so you don't fall off the scooter and hurt yourself.
reading_hint: You can't ride a scooter for a week barefoot, are you nuts?! Get some shoes!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rain</radical> is hated so much by <radical>wolverine</radical>s, so they always want to live in the <kanji>snow</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine rain falling on a wolverine and how much they hate it, so the wolverine moves up north to somewhere with lots of snow.
reading_mnemonic: You ask the wolverine, "Why do you want this <kanji>snow</kanji> so bad?" He replies quickly: "Because the rain is <reading>yucky</reading>" (ゆき).
reading_hint: He keeps saying "Yucky yucky yucky" over and over again. Imagine him doing this with an accent that would bring the word closer to ゆき.

meaning_mnemonic:
You look at a <radical>table</radical> and notice it is being used as a <radical>slide</radical> by <radical>insect</radical>s to launch themselves into the <kanji>wind</kanji>.

This kanji can also mean <kanji>style</kanji>. To remember this, consider how styles can change quickly, just like the <kanji>wind</kanji>!
meaning_hint: Picture a table tilted on its side with some of its legs longer than others, a perfect slide for insects! Imagine all the different insects jumping into the wind each in their own particular style.
reading_mnemonic: You wonder what's pushing these <kanji>insect</kanji>s to jump into the <kanji>wind</kanji> in such a manner, and you realize that it's because they've had way too much <reading>foo</reading>d (ふう).
reading_hint: The insects ate all the food that was left on the table, and now they can't just fly away into the wind like they normally do. Instead, they have to try this new style by using the table as a slide to help them take off into the wind.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>mouth</radical> and <radical>mustache</radical>, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how <kanji>tall</kanji> and <kanji>expensive</kanji> you are.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself saying how tall and expensive you are to everyone in the room. Then they use a lid to cover your mouth so you can't talk to anyone anymore. But, then your mustache starts talking, saying the same thing. That's why this lid covers both your mustache and your mouth. Now you can't say that you are tall or expensive.
reading_mnemonic:
"I am <kanji>tall</kanji>er and more <kanji>expensive</kanji> than you." 

You're saying this because there are some <reading>こう</reading>いちs in the room, and you want to make them feel inferior (you're a こういち hater). You keep comparing your height to the こういちs in the room, and you keep checking price tags. Then you tell them you're taller and more expensive than they are.
reading_hint: The こういちs finally get tired of your shenanigans, and lid up your mouth and mustache so you can't say that you're tall or expensive.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>fish</radical> and the kanji <kanji>fish</kanji> are exactly the same!
meaning_hint: Nothing fishy about that, right?
reading_mnemonic: You catch a <kanji>fish</kanji>. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: "<reading>GO</reading>!" (ぎょ). "GO GYO GYO GYO!" There's a huge cruise ship coming right towards your little fishing boat. No wonder the fish was yelling GO at you.
reading_hint: Have him continue to scream "GO GYO GYO GYO!" as you try to get your engine started and attempt to flee your impending doom. The fish helps too, because he's pretty worried as well.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bird</radical> radical and the <kanji>bird</kanji> kanji are the same!
meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical bird you know the kanji bird.
reading_mnemonic: Think of a run of the mill <kanji>bird</kanji>, whatever comes to mind for you first is fine. Then, your lovely bird swells. The shape of a face, then a hand, start stretching the bird apart until it explodes outward. Covered in blood and feathers is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう).
reading_hint: After bursting out of this bird, she turns her head sharply in your direction. "I don't just own the streets, I own the birds too. I'm inside every bird, and I, Mrs Chou, can burst out at any time."

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>yellow</radical> and the kanji <kanji>yellow</kanji> are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: You're in a room, surrounded completely by <kanji>yellow</kanji>. You can't get out. Somewhere in the room is a yellow <reading>key</reading> (き) but you can't find it, because everything looks the same. You crawl around trying to find this tiny thing so that you can escape.
reading_hint: The walls are coming in closer, too. Make sure you feel a bit of peril as you look for this key. The walls have a slight opening at the bottom too, so if you don't find it before the wall goes over it, the key will be lost forever, and you'll be smushed!

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>black</radical> and the kanji <kanji>black</kanji> are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: You're in a completely <kanji>black</kanji> room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's <reading>Coke</reading> (こく)! Mm, tasty Coke.
reading_hint: You need to drink all this Coke, otherwise you're going to drown. Drink this Coke and keep tasting its cold sweetness as you drink it all to survive.
